body:
>Changing World, Changing Mozilla
>Mitchell Baker August 11, 2020

>This is a time of change for the internet and for Mozilla. From combatting a lethal virus and battling systemic racism to protecting individual privacy — one thing is clear: an open and accessible internet is essential to the fight.

>Today we announced a significant restructuring of Mozilla Corporation. This will strengthen our ability to build and invest in products and services that will give people alternatives to conventional Big Tech. Sadly, the changes also include a significant reduction in our workforce by approximately 250 people.
>https://blog.mozilla.org/blog/2020/08/11/changing-world-changing-mozilla/
IT'S OVER
body_html:
Changing World, Changing Mozilla Mitchell Baker August 11, 2020

This is a time of change for the internet and for Mozilla. From combatting a lethal virus and battling systemic racism to protecting individual privacy — one thing is clear: an open and accessible internet is essential to the fight.

Today we announced a significant restructuring of Mozilla Corporation. This will strengthen our ability to build and invest in products and services that will give people alternatives to conventional Big Tech. Sadly, the changes also include a significant reduction in our workforce by approximately 250 people. https://blog.mozilla.org/blog/2020/08/11/changing-world-changing-mozilla/ IT'S OVER
title: Its over

body: I switched to the new Chromium Edge when it came out. Had Firefox since it was Phoenix and plain old "Mozilla Application Suite" (What Seamonkey became) before that. But they decided to ignore the very power users that made them successful.  Unfortunately HTML now means means Chromium Markup Language now and Firefox will be a Chromium skin soon.
body_html: I switched to the new Chromium Edge when it came out. Had Firefox since it was Phoenix and plain old "Mozilla Application Suite" (What Seamonkey became) before that. But they decided to ignore the very power users that made them successful. Unfortunately HTML now means means Chromium Markup Language now and Firefox will be a Chromium skin soon.

body: I don’t think there are any browsers that are not chromium based or whatever system Mozilla Firefox uses. Opera, Edge, Vivaldi, Dissenter, and obviously Chrome are all chromium-based (Chromium being developed by google). Firefox, Tor, and Waterfox are all based on gecko or something (Mozilla develops the gecko browser engine). The only major one that doesn’t use either of these is safari, but that’s still owned by Apple, and even then, Apple hasn’t released safari on windows for a looonnnggg... time. So AFAIK, there’s no reasonable alternatives.
body_html: I don’t think there are any browsers that are not chromium based or whatever system Mozilla Firefox uses. Opera, Edge, Vivaldi, Dissenter, and obviously Chrome are all chromium-based (Chromium being developed by google). Firefox, Tor, and Waterfox are all based on gecko or something (Mozilla develops the gecko browser engine). The only major one that doesn’t use either of these is safari, but that’s still owned by Apple, and even then, Apple hasn’t released safari on windows for a looonnnggg... time. So AFAIK, there’s no reasonable alternatives.

body:
You can still use tor without the tor browser bundle, but it's often ill-advised.

https://invidious.snopyta.org/watch?v=hcKpROGDXOM

Another option is i2p, though you will be staying only within the i2p network and not proxying out.
body_html:
You can still use tor without the tor browser bundle, but it's often ill-advised.

https://invidious.snopyta.org/watch?v=hcKpROGDXOM

Another option is i2p, though you will be staying only within the i2p network and not proxying out.

This will strengthen our ability to build and invest in products and services that will give people alternatives to conventional Big Tech. Sadly, the changes also include a significant reduction in our workforce by approximately 250 people.
>https://blog.mozilla.org/blog/2020/08/11/changing-world-changing-mozilla/
IT'S OVER
post.body_html:
Changing World, Changing Mozilla Mitchell Baker August 11, 2020

This is a time of change for the internet and for Mozilla. From combatting a lethal virus and battling systemic racism to protecting individual privacy — one thing is clear: an open and accessible internet is essential to the fight.

Today we announced a significant restructuring of Mozilla Corporation. This will strengthen our ability to build and invest in products and services that will give people alternatives to conventional Big Tech. Sadly, the changes also include a significant reduction in our workforce by approximately 250 people. https://blog.mozilla.org/blog/2020/08/11/changing-world-changing-mozilla/ IT'S OVER
post.title: Its over

body:
By spending money and donating funds.

And quite possibly, making Firefox terrible by embedding DNS sinkholes via DNS over HTTPS (this setting is default, and overrides your ISP's DNS while using the browser)

A few other devs have done this already, namely Fedilab & Tusky, (Fediverse mobile app clients) in regards to Gab.com in the past.
body_html:
By spending money and donating funds.

And quite possibly, making Firefox terrible by embedding DNS sinkholes via DNS over HTTPS (this setting is default, and overrides your ISP's DNS while using the browser)

A few other devs have done this already, namely Fedilab & Tusky, (Fediverse mobile app clients) in regards to Gab.com in the past.

parent.body: I don’t think there are any browsers that are not chromium based or whatever system Mozilla Firefox uses. Opera, Edge, Vivaldi, Dissenter, and obviously Chrome are all chromium-based (Chromium being developed by google). Firefox, Tor, and Waterfox are all based on gecko or something (Mozilla develops the gecko browser engine). The only major one that doesn’t use either of these is safari, but that’s still owned by Apple, and even then, Apple hasn’t released safari on windows for a looonnnggg... time. So AFAIK, there’s no reasonable alternatives.
parent.body_html: I don’t think there are any browsers that are not chromium based or whatever system Mozilla Firefox uses. Opera, Edge, Vivaldi, Dissenter, and obviously Chrome are all chromium-based (Chromium being developed by google). Firefox, Tor, and Waterfox are all based on gecko or something (Mozilla develops the gecko browser engine). The only major one that doesn’t use either of these is safari, but that’s still owned by Apple, and even then, Apple hasn’t released safari on windows for a looonnnggg... time. So AFAIK, there’s no reasonable alternatives.
